abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Primary School
            Development Project is unsatisfactory, although performance
            was mixed. Project outcomes are rated as satisfactory with
            respect to learning outcomes and enrollment in project
            schools. In all other areas, such as institutional
            development, community partnerships outside SIF schools,
            improved teaching, and improved supervision, the outcomes
            are unsatisfactory. Lessons were learned in the following
            areas: a) focus on the school and teachers - teachers must
            be given a chance to contribute to the design of education
            initiatives; b) community participation - increased
            involvement in the community in the development of the
            school and the establishment of partnerships between the
            community and school staff is linked to positive performance
            on all indicators; c) link between program design and
            institutional capacity - this relationship needs to be
            carefully assessed and adjustments made to phase
            implementation while building capacity; d) teacher
            incentives - little evidence to show these worked; e)
            strategies to increase enrolment - more adapted targeted
            nonformal approaches need to be developed; and f)
            prioritization of goals and strategies - persistent
            attention need be accorded to reaching all primary school
            aged children.
